title: La Flèche Wallonne 2025 preview: Routes, favourites, how to watch and start lists
content:
Cyclist
La Flèche Wallonne 2025 preview: Routes, favourites, how to watch and start lists

La Flèche Wallonne on Wednesday 23rd April marks the halfway point of cycling’s Ardennes week, flanked by the Amstel Gold Race and Liège-Bastogne-Liège. And in reality, it’s a race centred around a single climb: the famous Mur de Huy. Translated to ‘the Wall of Huy’, its position at the end of the race deals a knockout blow to anyone suffering before its 10% average, and brutal 26% max gradient.

La Flèche Wallonne was first run in 1936 to boost sales of the newspaper Les Sports. The men’s race became part of the WorldTour in 2009 while the women’s race was created in 1998 and gained WorldTour status in 2016. Anna van der Breggen’s dominance with seven consecutive victories helped earn her the nickname ‘Queen of the Ardennes’, while Alejandro Valverde holds the title for most wins in the men’s peloton with five.

In 2024, Stevie Williams won the men’s race in horrible conditions before Kasia Niewiadoma ended an almost five-year drought on the road in the women’s race.

La Flèche Wallonne 2025 key information

  • Date: Wednesday 23rd April 2025
  • Start: Women’s: Huy; Men’s: Ciney
  • Finish: Huy
  • Distance: Women’s: 140.7km; Men’s: 205.2km
  • Live TV coverage: TNT Sports, FloBikes, Peacock, SBS, Sporza
  • 2024 winners: Kasia Niewiadoma (Canyon-SRAM); Stevie Williams (Israel-Premier Tech)
  • Most wins: Anna van der Breggen (seven); Alejandro Valverde (five)

La Flèche Wallonne 2025 routes and profiles

Men’s route

Beginning in Ciney, the men’s race will travel over two small climbs before three laps around Huy that take in the Côte d’Ereffe (2.1km, 5%), Côte de Cherave (1.3km, 8.1%) and the Mur de Huy (1.2km, 10%). The final ascent of the Mur de Huy is the finishing point, an explosive last test between the field and victory.

Women’s route

The women’s parcours has changed with the climbs now totalling eight instead of seven. They will contend with two climbs before two laps of the same circuit as the men, and finishing at the top of the Mur de Huy.

La Flèche Wallonne 2025 favourites

2024 victors Williams and Niewiadoma will return to the start line to defend their titles. In the men’s race, Williams will be forced to face strong competition from Tadej Pogačar and Remco Evenepoel. In the women’s race, Demi Vollering will be looking for her first victory since Strade Bianche against Elisa Longo Borghini, Puck Pieterse and record holder Anna van der Breggen.

Cyclist’s ratings: Men’s race

  • ★★★★★: Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates XRG)
  • ★★★★: Remco Evenepoel (Soudal Quick-Step), Mattias Skjelmose (Lidl-Trek)
  • ★★★: Tom Pidcock (Q36.5 Pro Cycling), Oscar Onley (Picnic PostNL), Lenny Martinez (Bahrain Victorious), Lennert Van Eetvelt (Lotto)
  • ★★: Tiesj Benoot (Visma-Lease a Bike), Dani Martinez (Bahrain Victorious), Thibau Nys (Lidl-Trek), Enric Mas (Movistar)
  • ★: Ben Healy (EF Education-EasyPost), Kévin Vauquelin (Arkéa-B&B Hotels), Dylan Teuns (Cofidis), Romain Grégoire (Groupama-FDJ), Santiago Buitrago (Bahrain Victorious), Stevie Williams (Israel-Premier Tech), Clément Champoussin (XDS-Astana)

Cyclist’s ratings: Women’s race

  • ★★★★★: Demi Vollering (FDJ-Suez)
  • ★★★★: Elisa Longo Borghini (UAE Team ADQ), Puck Pieterse (Fenix-Deceuninck), Liane Lippert (Movistar)
  • ★★★: Kasia Niewiadoma (Canyon-SRAM-Zondacrypto), Évita Muzic (FDJ-Suez), Niamh Fisher-Black (Lidl-Trek)
  • ★★: Juliette Labous (FDJ-Suez), Neve Bradbury (Canyon-SRAM-Zondacrypto), Gaia Realini (Lidl-Trek), Anna van der Breggen (SD Worx-Protime)
  • ★: Noemi Rüegg (EF Education-Oatly), Ashleigh Moolman-Pasio (AG Insurance-Soudal), Yara Kastelijn (Alpecin-Deceuninck), Marta Cavalli (Picnic-PostNL)

La Flèche Wallonne 2025: How to watch

The 2025 La Flèche Wallonne races will be available to watch in the UK on TNT Sports 1 and Discovery+ from 11:45 on Wednesday 23rd April. The men’s race is up first with the broadcast expected to finish at 15:45. The women’s event will be broadcast straight after on TNT Sports 1 and Discovery until 17:15.

Over in the USA and Canada, the action will be available on FloBikes from 06:45 EST, it’s also being broadcast on Peacock in the USA. In Australia, both races will be broadcast on SBS On Demand.

If the race isn’t being broadcast in your country or you are travelling abroad, a VPN will allow you to hide your device’s location to access content that is normally geo-blocked. One such VPN provider is ExpressVPN, which is well reviewed, helps users to find free to watch cycling, and costs start from around £5 per month.

  • Read more: How to watch cycling for less in the UK
  • Read more: Which countries can watch cycling for free in 2025?
